dataObjects.bibliographicCitation: Dahanukar, N. 2010. Badis kanabos. In: IUCN 2014 . IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2014.1 . <www.iucnredlist.org>
dataObjects.description: This species is reported from the middle reaches of the Brahmaputra River in India (German-Indian Expedition, 1957, type locality unclear; given on type specimen label as 'Raimona' (Assam)). Concluded to mean Raimana by Kullander and Britz (2002). There are also records from the Bhoroli, Janali, and Sukajan Rivers and from Kokrajhar in Assam. It has also been collected more recently (W. Vishwanath pers. comm. 2010) from one other locality in western Assam.

dataObjects.description: Dorsal spines (total): 15 - 17; Dorsal soft rays (total): 8 - 10; Analsoft rays: 6 - 8; Vertebrae: 26 - 28

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObjects.description: Possesses a conspicuous dark blotch covering the superficial part of cleithrum above the pectoral fin base; absence of a dark caudal peduncle blotch.  Body depth 29.9-35.4%SL; interorbital width 7.3-8.6% SL.  Conspicuous dark blotch anteriorly in the dorsal fin, between 3rd-5th spine.  Distal extrascapular present.  Vertical bars on sides as multiple emphasized narrow lines.  Caudal fin with dark bar across base or midbasal rounded dark blotch (Ref. 46238).

dataObjects.bibliographicCitation: Dahanukar, N. 2010. Badis kanabos. In: IUCN 2014 . IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2014.1 . <www.iucnredlist.org>
dataObjects.description:
Red List Category
DD
Data Deficient

Red List Criteria

Version
3.1

Year Assessed
2010

Assessor/s
Dahanukar, N.

Reviewer/s
Britz, R., Dey, S.C., Jha, B.R., Vishwanath, W. & Allen, D.J.

Contributor/s
Molur, S.

Justification
Since Badis kanabos is a newly described species more information is required for a proper understanding of this species, and it is at present assessed as Data Deficient. This species is reported from the lower reaches of Brahmaputra river in India and from one other recent location much further to the west in Assam. It is possible that this species is more widely present within the area and might eventually qualify for Least Concern if more information is available from surveys and research.
